lesson_plan.description: Understanding the concept of clustering and its applications. Types of clustering algorithms.
Overview of the K-Means algorithm, its working principle, and key concepts like centroids, clusters, and distance metrics.
Detailed explanation of the steps involved in the K-Means algorithm, including initialization, assignment, and update phases.

lesson_plan.topic_name: Choosing the Optimal Number of Clusters (K)
lesson_plan.description: Methods for determining the optimal value of K, such as the Elbow method and silhouette analysis.
Hands-on implementation of the K-Means algorithm using Python libraries like scikit-learn.
Exploring real-world applications of K-Means clustering in various domains like customer segmentation, image compression, and anomaly detection.
Discussion on the strengths and limitations of the K-Means algorithm, including sensitivity to initial centroids and difficulty with non-spherical clusters.
Exploring variations of the K-Means algorithm, such as K-Means++, Mini Batch K-Means, and Fuzzy C-Means.
Understanding how to evaluate the performance of K-Means clustering using metrics like inertia, silhouette score, and Davies-Bouldin index.
Analyzing a real-world dataset using K-Means clustering, including data preparation, model training, and result interpretation.
Addressing the limitations of K-Means clustering and exploring alternative clustering algorithms like hierarchical clustering and DBSCAN.
Exploring advanced topics related to K-Means clustering, such as handling categorical data, dealing with outliers, and scaling features.
Working on a project that involves applying K-Means clustering to solve a real-world problem.
Reviewing the key concepts covered in the lesson plan and addressing any remaining questions.
